title: Zero to 16383 Through the Wire: Transmitting High-Resolution MIDI with WebSockets and the Browser
author: Daniel McKemie (Independent Artist)
relevance_why: This paper explores MIDI data transmission through web technologies, which could inform applications in audio processing and music generation that align with Dr. Liu’s research focus.
background: This study focuses on transmitting high-resolution MIDI messages over the internet using WebSockets, enabling control of musical applications through browsers.
contribution: This paper introduces a method for leveraging the Web MIDI API and WebSockets to send 14-bit MIDI messages, achieving greater flexibility in musical application control.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous approaches lacked efficient web integration for real-time MIDI control, often relying on direct hardware connections or limited browser compatibility.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by employing the Web MIDI API for direct browser integration, facilitating remote music application control without local dependency.

key_innovation: Seamlessly combines web technology and MIDI control to allow users to interact with musical software remotely, thus expanding performance and collaboration potential.
real_world_impact: The method proposed could enhance live audio performances and collaborative software tools, encouraging remote participation in musical environments.
limitations: The paper notes security concerns with the Web MIDI API and limited browser support, particularly on Safari and Firefox.

new_terms.Control Change (CC): **Control Change (CC)** messages are used in MIDI to send various types of control information, allowing for dynamic changes in a musical performance.
new_terms.Most Significant Byte (MSB): **Most Significant Byte (MSB)** represents the upper byte of a 14-bit value, allowing for greater resolution in MIDI data.
new_terms.Least Significant Byte (LSB): **Least Significant Byte (LSB)** refers to the lower byte in a 14-bit MIDI value, used in tandem with the MSB.
